posts.name:
Nuwpur Jain
Nuwpur Jain
posts.content:
My dadi died 7 days back BUT she lived an absolutely full life which shocks me even today

Here's what made her extraordinary:

1) The Family Matriarch: She nurtured an incredible legacy of 51 hearts - 6 children, 18 grandchildren, and 27 great-grandchildren. Each one carrying a piece of her boundless love.

2) The Eternal Explorer: At 80+, she had the curiosity of a 21-year-old, traveling from Singapore to Dubai, and finally to Ram Mandir - living life with more enthusiasm than people a quarter her age.

3) The Graceful Goodbye: Seven days ago, she left us exactly how she lived - peacefully, having fulfilled all her wishes, and without suffering. A perfect ending to a life lived perfectly.

Here's to you, Dadi - forever young, forever loved ️

comments.commentText: Nuwpur, your tribute to your grandmother beautifully captures the essence of a remarkable life well-lived. Her legacy of love and curiosity is truly inspiring and serves as a reminder of how to embrace life fully, regardless of age. Thank you for sharing such heartfelt memories.
Priyank Ahuja Living proof that the best things in life come without an expiry date

posts.name:
Devan Bhalla
Devan Bhalla
posts.content:
This 
hashtag
#IPS officer failed thrice before cracking India’s toughest exam with an AIR 217. A nanoscience researcher, she decided to pursue a career in civil services and bring large scale impact. This is the story of IPS Anu Beniwal 

Born on April 26th, 1992, in Pitampura village (Delhi) in a middle-class family, she was always someone who wanted to do more with life.

Her father had to step back from work due to his ill-health but that never stopped the family from supporting her decisions.

She went on to pursue her Bachelors and Masters in Physics from Hindu College (Delhi University) followed by a stint in research in nanoscience.

She decided to transition towards Civil Services and set out to prepare for UPSC CSE but failed in her first two attempts.

She secured an AIR 638 in her third attempt and was allotted the DANIPS cadre but it was her fourth attempt when she secured the berth of an IPS with an AIR 217.

She is currently posted under the Madhya Pradesh cadre as the SDOP of Manavar post.

She was previously posted as an SHO in Gwalior and was lauded for her work against the sand mafia.

Her story goes on to show that you can should always pursue your dreams, no matter how difficult the situation is.

Onwards & Upwards.

P.S.: Taking this opportunity to invite opinions from civil servants on how to drive better law and order sensitization amongst the civilians.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

Followfor your brand x business content.
(Hit theicon on my profile for the latest updates)

comments.commentText: Such an inspiring journey
Sumit Thank you for the comment! What drives individuals to keep pushing forward after multiple failures, especially in challenging exams like UPSC?

posts.name:
Ajay Prasad
Ajay Prasad
posts.content:
𝗥𝗲𝗳𝗹𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗼𝗻 𝗙𝗮𝗶𝗹𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝘀 𝗣𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝗦𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 

After 40+ years in business, I’ve come to see failure as an essential, often underestimated part of success. How we handle failure, not the number of times we fail, defines our growth and resilience. In business and life, taking risks often leads to setbacks, yet each failure is a learning opportunity that fuels progress.

Recently, I read an essay on the common pitfalls of high-potential startups and saw valuable lessons we can apply to our own paths.

𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗸𝗲𝘆 𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲𝗮𝘄𝗮𝘆𝘀:

𝟭. 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗱𝘂𝗰𝘁-𝗠𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁 𝗙𝗶𝘁: If the product doesn’t solve customer needs, it has no place in the market.
𝟮. 𝗙𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹 𝗗𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲: Businesses struggle when they overspend or take on excessive debt. Building slowly, within means, is a powerful path to sustainable growth.
𝟯. 𝗟𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝗖𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿𝘀: Ignoring feedback on products or why prospects don’t convert is a critical error.
𝟰. 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆: Competing directly with giants often backfires. It’s better to carve out a niche where established players aren’t willing to go.
𝟱. 𝗧𝗶𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴: Entering the market too early or late can make or break a business.
𝟲. 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 & 𝗧𝗲𝗮𝗺: Companies fail due to ineffective leadership or team dynamics. Staying grounded in customer needs, over quick wins, is crucial.

𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗧𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗧𝗵𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗝𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗦𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴:

• 𝗠𝗮𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗩𝗶𝗴𝗶𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲: Regularly review assumptions, results, and adapt to improve performance.
• 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝘆 𝗧𝗿𝘂𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗖𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗩𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲𝘀: Our mission should always serve customer needs, anchoring us to what drives real value.
• 𝗙𝗮𝗰𝗲 𝗥𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆: Build on strengths, address weaknesses, and avoid ventures outside our core competencies.
• 𝗗𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘄𝘁𝗵: Focus on sustainable growth within means, prioritizing resilience over rapid expansion.
• 𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗴-𝗧𝗲𝗿𝗺 𝗩𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻: Embrace a vision for sustainable success, choosing stability over risky short-term gains.

By embracing calculated risks, adapting quickly to failure, and committing to lessons learned, we can foster enduring success. Here’s to turning setbacks into stepping stones for growth.

posts.name:
Shulin Lee
Shulin Lee
posts.content:
7 WORST Things to Do When Exiting a Company  

(and what to do instead!)

People think once they’ve resigned,
it’s game over.

But how you leave matters just as much
as how you started.

Don’t wreck your reputation!

Here’s how NOT to exit,
(and what to do instead:)

1/ Burn Bridges. 
↳ That dramatic exit you're imagining? Forget it.
↳ Instead, leave on good terms.

2/ Slack Off in your Final Weeks. 
↳ Tempted to coast to the finish line? Don’t.
↳ Show your integrity.

3/ Drop a Resignation Bomb. 
↳ Surprising your manager with a sudden exit? Bad move.
↳ Instead, communicate early and give them time.

4/ Bash the Company On Your Way Out. 
↳ Frustrated? Venting might feel good in the moment.
↳ Channel that energy into constructive feedback.

5/ Neglect Proper Handover. 
↳ Leaving your work in a mess? Not cool.
↳ Do detailed handover notes for a smooth transition.

6/ Ghost your Colleagues. 
↳ Disappearing without a word? Big mistake.
↳ Acknowledge the relationships you’ve built.

7/ Forget your Exit is Part of Your Legacy. ‍️
↳ This isn’t an ending—it’s a step in your journey.
↳ Stay connected. Never know when you’ll cross paths again.

It’s a small world,
and people remember how you made them feel.

Leave the right way.
Your reputation depends on it.

P.S. Each one of these came from a


---

Repost this to help someone today!

 Followfor more.

comments.commentText: Shulin Lee one of the kindest exits I have seen happened years ago. On returning their equipment they took the time to package and wrap with extra care so the computers wouldn’t break but the best part of opening their returned equipment was a hand written note thanking us for the opportunity to work here and having gratitude. I let them know if on their journey they ever needed a reference I would be happy to give one. Years have passed since then and I received a kind text a month or so ago asking for help. I made sure to give them my email, calendar link, and cell for their references. Be kind you never know how your paths can cross again.
Jennelle McGrath such a great example of how small gestures can go a long way. You never know when that kindness comes back around. Thank you for sharing :)
Shulin Lee

Shulin, I mastered these coutesies when I was 17.

Toxic companies do not extend the same,
and this a BIGGER problem. There are enough toxic companies that warrant exposure.

They burn bridges and black list employees.
They sever the relationship immediately. The employee is gone, no slacking.
Companies drop the layoff bomb, give no answers, and they are cruel in this message.
They kill employee’s chances of getting another job through illegal slander thinking they won’t be caught.
Employees laid off with no notice leaves a mess, and companies don’t care who has to clean it up.
 Colleagues ghost departing employees, not the other way around.
The employee’s legacy is painted by the company: failure, incompetent, stupid, trash.

Lot’s of great talent got laid off in the last two years, and the trauma persists. This post perpetuates their Imposter Syndrome, “I guess I was not good enogh.”

My recommendation: rewrite this and appeal to an audience who needs to see this. Do the right thing and hold these toxic companies accountable!

Friends: not all companies are toxic and will not do ANY of these actions. I support those companies.  Job search with caution.

Toni Emery Thanks for sharing your perspective. It's unfortunate when people are treated poorly, and those behaviors should definitely be held accountable. However, the aim of this post is to empower professionals to leave with dignity and maintain a positive reputation, regardless of the situation they’re in.

Leaving with grace doesn’t mean tolerating bad behavior ~ it's about protecting your own integrity and reputation, which is something that no one can take away from you.

The hope is to provide advice to help professionals navigate their exits in ways that set them up for future success, even in challenging situations.

posts.name:
Danish R
Danish R
posts.content:
BluSmart has left me with a broken nose, a fractured cheekbone, trauma for life—and they’ve offered zero compensation, zero accountability, and zero remorse.

I have been following up via email for a month, and I think I have waited enough.

Here’s what happened:

- On December 7, 2024, while riding in a Blu Smart cab, the driver jumped a red signal and collided with a truck.

- The accident left me severely injured, requiring surgery and a recovery period of three months.

- The driver admitted that the car’s brakes had failed, yet he knowingly chose to drive the vehicle, putting my life in danger.


Blu Smart’s response so far:

- Despite multiple emails, including to the leadership team, there has been no meaningful action or accountability.

- Instead of addressing the issue, their response team had the audacity to tell me that 'If the car's break had failed, the accident would have happened a long time ago during the ride'


The toll on me:

- Over ₹2,00,000 in medical expenses so far, with more to come.

- The physical and emotional trauma for me and my family is immeasurable.

I trusted Blu Smart as a safe and reliable service, but this incident has completely shattered that trust.

What kind of company behaves this way?
Blu Smart is perceived as one of the safest cab services—but is that reputation just a facade?

Driver errors can happen, but:

- The car should be safe.

- The company should step up to take responsibility. Here, all three failed—the car, the driver, and Blu Smart's accountability.

I didn't wanna do this but I think everyone deserves to know the truth about their service.

comments.commentText: Hi, just saw this. Let me look into this and get back. Not sure if there's some gap in the system that has missed this getting escalated. Hope you're getting better! Will speak soon.
Anirudh Arun I'm getting better. Thank you.

Anirudh Arun That's a customer-centric approach by BluSmart! Providing prompt and fair compensation to customers who have experienced issues can indeed help maintain their trust and loyalty. This proactive step can also enhance BluSmart's reputation and prestige in the market.

Irrespective of the condition of the brake, if you have suffered while you were using their services, they are liable to pay you for the damage. You just need to hire a good lawyer and sue them in court. Demand all the direct/indirect (including trauma) expenses/loss due to the accident.
Gunanidhi Hegde I did not have the mental strength to do any of it. Everyday when I looked at my face in the mirror, it broke me. It's today that I got the strength to post this.

posts.name:
Jeff Martin
Jeff Martin
posts.content:
Every journey kicks off with just one step, and every epic story begins with a single page. Here’s the thing: we don’t get to rewind and redo the past, but the future? That’s all in your hands.

Today isn’t just another day—it’s your canvas. Your shot to splash dreams, resilience, and hustle all over it.

The pen is yours. The power is yours. To flip the script, to rewrite the story, to build something fueled by grit, guts, and unwavering belief in yourself.

Yeah, the past left its mark. But the future? That’s for you to shape into something extraordinary. Don’t wait for perfect conditions—get moving now. Start messy, start unsure, but start.

Write yourself a story packed with growth, wins, and living up to your full potential. Let’s make it happen.

The future is yours—grab it!

LFG

comments.commentText: Love the idea of taking control of our narrative and crafting our success stories.
The concept of seeing each day as an opportunity resonates deeply with me.

posts.name:
Neha Rani
Neha Rani
posts.content:
𝑱𝒂𝒏𝒖𝒂𝒓𝒚 𝒊𝒏 𝑩𝒊𝒉𝒂𝒓 = ️ 𝑫𝒂𝒉𝒊 +  𝑪𝒉𝒖𝒅𝒂 +  𝑻𝒊𝒍𝒌𝒖𝒕 = 𝑷𝒖𝒓𝒆 𝑱𝒐𝒚!


What’s winter without the taste of home?  In
, January isn’t complete without the iconic trio of creamy curd, soft flattened rice, and the sweet crunch of sesame-jaggery Tilkut.

It’s not just a meal—it’s a tradition that wraps you in nostalgia and takes you back to chilly mornings, family laughter, and the spirit of Makar Sankranti. 

Simple yet soulful, this combination is proof that the best things in life are often the simplest. It’s more than food—it’s a celebration of culture, community, and love.


Have you tried this taste of Bihar yet? If not, you’re missing a slice of heaven! 


Wishing everyone a 𝐇𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐲 𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐚𝐫 𝐒𝐚𝐧𝐤𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐭𝐢! May this festive season bring you happiness, warmth, and prosperity.


Drop your favorite winter tradition or dish in the comments below.

comments.commentText: Neha, your words beautifully capture the essence of Bihar's warmth and traditions. It's true that food often transcends mere sustenance; it connects us to our roots, our family, and our shared memories. Thank you for reminding us of the joy that comes from these simple yet profound experiences. Wishing you a joyful Makar Sankranti filled with love and togetherness!

posts.name:
Naman Bajaj
Naman Bajaj
posts.content:
Did you know that we deliberately add microplastic to a range of products, from cosmetics to paints & adhesives? This team has found a nature-based solution for that...

Microplastics are these super tiny plastic particles.

They are smaller than 5mm.

And they are basically everywhere now.

From the mountain peaks to the ocean trenches.

They usually break off from bigger plastic.

So they are called secondary microplastic.

But here’s the surprising thing.

We have something called primary microplastic.

Where we consciously produce microplastic.

An estimated 2 million tonnes of it every year.

And add it to various products.

Like cosmetics, paints, detergents & adhesives.

To improve their performance.

is tackling this primary microplastic crisis.

With an innovative solution.

It has developed biodegradable cellulose microspheres.

The cellulose comes from certified forestry.

Or agricultural waste.

Made using energy-efficient manufacturing.

And with non-toxic, recyclable solvents.

This can replace the primary microplastic

That can replace microplastics in everything.

Delivering the same performance.

While being environmentally friendly.

***
Story 505/1000- on a spree to publish 1000 impactful stories in 1000 days.

If you want to learn more about initiatives such as Naturbeads that are positively impacting the planet, you would love my weekly newsletter ‍️Not My Problem.

posts.name:
Divya Pahil
Divya Pahil
posts.content:
Red Flags You Need to Quit Your Job Immediately!

- Your salary is always late.
- The owner watches the CCTV cameras all day.
- They keep calling you on your day off.
- When someone leaves the company, they’re treated like an enemy.
- You’re limited to only two cups of tea a day.
- You can only eat lunch in a specific area.
- You can't take days off on Friday or Monday because of a "sandwich" rule.
- Even if you're five seconds late, your pay gets docked.
- You’re getting used to calling people "Sir" and "Ma'am."
- They keep calling you on your day off.
- Only those who "lift" get promoted.

Anything else to add?

comments.commentText: What is this sandwich rule ?
Rahul S. Nothing is confusing. It’s very much clear
Divya Pahil it is, around and between have different meaning

Absolutely true! I’ve worked in an organization that exhibited all these red flags. I chose to stay at the time because it was during the COVID period—a time of uncertainty and limited options.
However, if you ask me today, my answer would be a resounding NO! 
Sometimes, experience teaches us what we deserve and what we should never settle for
RESHMA SUVARRNA Right

One of the first things I train our salespeople is that we don’t sell.

Period.

We look for people with a problem and offer a solution- if we have one.

Sounds easy?

It’s not.

Most salespeople are too focused on closing. That’s why most salespeople suck.

,, there is a reason people love working with you guys 

(If you’re someone who actually wants to help people and solve real problems, we’re hiring sales reps who think differently. Let’s talk)


___
